resources.string: Currant, Plum, Black Cherry and Spice, with notes of Olive, Vanilla Mint, Tobacco, Toasty Cedar, Anise, Pepper and Herbs. Full-bodied wines with great depth that improve with aging. Cabernet spends from 15 to 30 months aging in American and French Oak barrels which tend to soften the tannins, adding the toasty cedar and vanilla flavors.

Red wine grape used in Bordeaux for blending with Cabernet Sauvignon. It is an earlier-maturing red wine, due to its lower level of tannins. Light to medium-bodied wine with more immediate fruit than Cabernet Sauvignon and some of the herbaceous odors evident in unripe Cabernet Sauvignon.

Herbs, Green Olive, Cherry and Chocolate. Softer and medium in weight with fewer tannins than Cabernet and ready to drink sooner. Takes well to Oak aging. It is frequently used as a blending wine with Cabernet to soften

This is the great, noble grape of Burgundy. Difficult to grow but at its best it is smooth and richer than Cabernet Sauvignon with less tannin. Raisin like flavors with undertones of black cherry, spice and raspberry. Widely used in the making of champagne sparkling wines.

With predominant raspberry flavors and a spicy aroma, Zinfandels can be bold and intense as well as light and fruity. It takes well to blending bringing out flavors of cherry, wild berry and plum with notes of leather, earth and tar. It is the most widely grown grape in California. Much of it is turned into White Zinfandel, a blush wine that is slightly sweet.
From a blend of grapes this fruity, light ruby-to-garnet-colored red may be called Chianti Riserva when aged three or more years
Known for its supple texture, medium to full-bodied spice flavors, raspberry cherry and anise. Sangiovese is used in many fine Italian wines including Chianti
British term for red Bordeaux/Cabernet Sauvignon wines.

Once important in Bordeaux and the Loire in various blends, this not-very-hardy grape has been steadily replaced by Merlot and the two Cabernets. However, Argentina is markedly successful with this varietal. Plum and blackberry flavors mark this deep, ruby colored wine. Usually full-bodied with chewy tannins. Used in France and California as a blending wine. Not related to the Syrah of France
Fortified wine from the Douro region of Portugal. Styles include: Late Bottle (LB), Tawny, Ruby, Aged, and Vintage. Mostly sweet and red
Sometimes called blush. Any light pink wine, dry to sweet, made by removing the skins of red grapes early in the fermentation process or by mixing red and white
